head.title: Applying Blind Chaos Control to Find Periodic Orbits

article.h1: Applying Blind Chaos Control to Find Periodic Orbits

span.span:
Daniel T. Kaplan
Department of Mathematics and Computer Science
Macalester College
St. Paul, Minnesota 55105

p.span:
Abstract: Analysis of the PPF chaos control method used in biological experiments shows that it can robustly control a wider class of systems than previously believed, including those without stable manifolds. This can be exploited to find the locations of unstable periodic orbits by varying the parameters of the control system.
PACS numbers: 87.10.+e, 05.45.+b, 07.05.Dz

div.p: One of the most surprising successes of chaos theory has been in biology: the experimentally demonstrated ability to control the timing of spikes of electrical activity in complex and apparently chaotic systems such as heart tissue [1] and brain tissue [2]. In these experiments, PPF control â€” a modified formulation of OGY control [3] â€” was applied to set the timing of external stimuli; the controlled system showed stable periodic trajectories instead of the irregular interspike intervals seen in the uncontrolled system. The mechanism of control in these experiments was interpreted originally as analogous to that of OGY control: unstable periodic orbits riddle the chaotic attractor and the electrical stimuli place the systemâ€™s state on the stable manifold of one of these periodic orbits.

Alternative possible mechanisms for the experimental observations have been described by Zeng and Glass [4] and Christini and Collins [5]. These authors point out that the controlling external stimuli serve to truncate the interspike interval to a maximum value. When applied, the control stimulus sets the next interval sn+1subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{n+1} to be on the line

semantics.annotation: italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-A italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus caligraphic-C PERIOD:.

div.p: We will call this relationship the â€œcontrol line.â€ Zeng and Glass showed that if the uncontrolled relationship between interspike intervals is a chaotic one-dimensional function, sn+1=fâ¢(sn)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)s_{n+1}=f(s_{n}), then the control system effectively flattens the top of this map and the controlled dynamics may have fixed points or other periodic orbits[4]. Christini and Collins showed that behavior analogous to the fixed-point control seen in the biological experiments can be accomplished even in completely random systems[5]. Since neither chaotic one-dimensional systems nor random systems have a stable manifold, the interval-truncation interpretation of the biological experiments is different than the OGY interpretation. The interval-truncation method differs also from OGY and related control methods in that the perturbing control input is a fixed-size stimulus whose timing can be treated as a continuous parameter. This type of input is conventional in cardiology (e.g., [6]).

In this Letter, we show that the state-trunction interpretation is applicable in cases where there is a stable manifold of a periodic orbit as well as in cases where there are only unstable manifolds. We find that superior control can be achieved by intentionally placing the systemâ€™s state off of any stable manifold. This suggests a powerful scheme for the rapid experimental identification of fixed points and other periodic orbits in systems where interspike intervals are of interest.

The chaos control in [1] and [2] was implemented in two stages. First, interspike intervals snsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{n} from the uncontrolled, â€œnaturalâ€ system were observed. Modeling the system as a function of two variables sn+1=fâ¢(sn,sn-1)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)s_{n+1}=f(s_{n},s_{n-1}), the location sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star} of a putative unstable flip-saddle type fixed point and the corresponding stable eigenvalue Î»ssubscriptğœ†ğ‘ italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{s} were estimated from the data.[7] (Since the fixed point is unstable, there is also an unstable eigenvalue Î»usubscriptğœ†ğ‘¢italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{u}.) The linear approximation to the stable manifold lies on a line given by Eq. 1 with ğ’œ=Î»sğ’œsubscriptğœ†ğ‘ caligraphic-A RELOP:equals italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal A}=\lambda_{s} and ğ’=(1-Î»s)â¢sâ‹†ğ’1subscriptğœ†ğ‘ superscriptğ‘ â‹†caligraphic-C RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal C}=(1-\lambda_{s})s^{\star}. Second, using estimated values of ğ’œğ’œcaligraphic-A{\cal A} and ğ’ğ’caligraphic-C{\cal C}, the control system was turned on. Following each observed interval snsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{n}, the maximum allowed value of the next interspike interval was computed as ğ’®n+1=ğ’œâ¢sn+ğ’subscriptğ’®ğ‘›1ğ’œsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ’caligraphic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-A italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus caligraphic-C{\cal S}_{n+1}={\cal A}s_{n}+{\cal C}. If the next interval naturally was shorter than ğ’®n+1subscriptğ’®ğ‘›1caligraphic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal S}_{n+1} no control stimulus was applied to the system. Otherwise, an external stimulus was provided to truncate the interspike interval at sn+1=ğ’®n+1subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1subscriptğ’®ğ‘›1italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{n+1}={\cal S}_{n+1}. [8]

In practice, the values of sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star} and Î»ssubscriptğœ†ğ‘ italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{s} for a real fixed point of the natural system are known only imperfectly from the data. Insofar as the estimates are inaccurate, the control system does not place the state on the true stable manifold. Therefore, we will analyze the controlled system without presuming that ğ’œğ’œcaligraphic-A{\cal A} and ğ’ğ’caligraphic-C{\cal C} in Eq. 1 correspond to the stable manifold.

If the natural dynamics of the system is modeled by sn+1=fâ¢(sn,sn-1)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)s_{n+1}=f(s_{n},s_{n-1}), the dynamics of the controlled system is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ATOM:min OPEN:{ ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-f OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CELL:end CELL:start ATOM:NaturalDynamics CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start caligraphic-A italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus caligraphic-C CELL:end CELL:start ATOM:ControlLine CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

div.p: We can study the dynamics of the controlled system close to a natural fixed point, sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star}, by approximating the natural dynamics linearly [9] as

semantics.annotation: italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

OPEN:( italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

ADDOP:plus italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

div.p: Since the controlled system (Eq. 2 is nonlinear even when fâ¢()ğ‘“italic-f OPEN:( CLOSE:)f() is linear, it is difficult to analyze its behavior by algebraic iteration. Nonetheless, the controlled system can be studied in terms of one-dimensional maps.

Following any interspike interval when the controlling stimulus has been applied, the systemâ€™s state (sn,sn-1)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(s_{n},s_{n-1}) will lie somewhere on the control line. From this time onward the state will lie on an image of the control line even if additional stimuli are applied during future interspike intervals.

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: Successive images of the control line for a flip saddle with Î»s=0.3subscriptğœ†ğ‘ 0.3italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.3\lambda_{s}=0.3, Î»u=-2.7subscriptğœ†ğ‘¢2.7italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.7\lambda_{u}=-2.7, ğ’œ=-0.1ğ’œ0.1caligraphic-A RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.1{\cal A}=-0.1, and xâ‹†-sâ‹†=-.75superscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†.75italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:.75x^{\star}-s^{\star}=-.75. Left: the control line is shown as the broad dark gray line. Its image under the natural dynamics is shown as a dashed line; the image under the control dynamics is the bent light gray line. Right: the first image of the control line is replotted. The image of this under the natural dynamics is the dashed line; the image under the control dynamics is the solid line.

div.p: Figure 1 (left) shows an example of how the dynamics result in a simple one-dimensional map for the case where the natural dynamics have a flip saddle (Î»u<-1subscriptğœ†ğ‘¢1italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1\lambda_{u}<-1 and 0<Î»s<10subscriptğœ†ğ‘ 1NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:10<\lambda_{s}<1) and where the control line intersects the line of identity (sn=sn-1subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{n}=s_{n-1}) below the natural fixed point sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star}. The stable and unstable manifolds are shown as arrows which intersect at the location of the natural fixed point sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star}. The control line is shown as a broad dark gray stripe. Its image under the natural dynamics is shown as a thin dashed line. At some points this image is above the control line and is therefore truncated (in the vertical direction) by the control stimulus to be on the control line. Overall, the image of the control line under the controlled dynamics is shown as the broad light gray bent line. In this case, the first, second, and all successive images of the control line are all the same: see Fig 1 (right).

Once the control stimulus has been applied, the dynamics of the controlled system are described by a one-dimensional map: the bent light gray line in Fig. 1. The analysis of the dynamics of this map is straightforward. For the case shown in Fig. 1, the map has a fixed point (where the flat part of the map intersects the line of identity). Near this fixed point, the map is identical to the control line, so the fixed point of the map is also the â€œcontroller fixed point,â€

semantics.annotation: italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-C MULOP:divide OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus caligraphic-A CLOSE:)

div.p: where the control line intersects the line of identity.

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: Successive images of the control line for a non-flip saddle: Î»s=0.3subscriptğœ†ğ‘ 0.3italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.3\lambda_{s}=0.3, Î»u=2.7subscriptğœ†ğ‘¢2.7italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.7\lambda_{u}=2.7, ğ’œ=-0.1ğ’œ0.1caligraphic-A RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.1{\cal A}=-0.1, xâ‹†-sâ‹†=.5superscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†.5italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:.5x^{\star}-s^{\star}=.5. (See Fig. 1 for the key.) The stable fixed point of the controlled dynamics is located just to the right of the elbow in the image of the control line.

div.p: Figure 2 illustrates a more complicated case, a non-flip saddle with xâ‹†>sâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star}>s^{\star}, where successive images of the control line do not all overlap. In this case, successive images are not identical, but there is still a stable fixed point of the controlled dynamics at xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star}.

The stability of the controlled dynamics fixed point and the size of its basin of attraction can be analyzed in terms of the control line and its image. When the previous interspike interval has been terminated by a control stimulus, the state lies somewhere on the control line. If the controlled dynamics are to have a stable fixed point, this must be at the controller fixed point xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} where the control line intersects the line of identity. However, the controller fixed point need not be a fixed point of the controlled dynamics. For example, if the image of the controller fixed point is below the controller fixed point, then the interspike interval following a stimulus will be terminated naturally.

For the controller fixed point to be a fixed point of the controlled dynamics, we require that the natural image of the controller fixed point be at or above the controller fixed point. One such situation, for the flip saddle, is illustrated in Fig. 1 where it can be seen [10] that the natural image of a neighborhood of the control line near xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} is above the control line. Thus the dynamics of the controlled system, close to xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star}, are given simply by

semantics.annotation: italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-A italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus caligraphic-C

div.p: The fixed point of these dynamics is stable so long as -1<ğ’œ<11ğ’œ1ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 RELOP:less-than caligraphic-A RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1-1<{\cal A}<1. In the case of a flip saddle, we therefore have a simple recipe for successful state-truncation control: position xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} below the natural fixed point sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star} and set -1<ğ’œ<11ğ’œ1ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 RELOP:less-than caligraphic-A RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1-1<{\cal A}<1.

Fixed points of the controlled dynamics can exist for natural dynamics other than flip saddles. This can be seen using the following reasoning: Let Î¾ğœ‰italic-xi\xi be the difference between the controller fixed point and the natural fixed point: sâ‹†=xâ‹†+Î¾superscriptğ‘ â‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğœ‰italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-xis^{\star}=x^{\star}+\xi. Then the natural image of the controller fixed point can be found from Eq. 3 to be

semantics.annotation: italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

OPEN:( italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

ADDOP:plus OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-xi CLOSE:)

div.p: The condition that

semantics.annotation: italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equals italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: will be satisfied depending only on Î»ssubscriptğœ†ğ‘ italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{s}, Î»usubscriptğœ†ğ‘¢italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{u}, and Î¾=sâ‹†-xâ‹†ğœ‰superscriptğ‘ â‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-xi RELOP:equals italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\xi=s^{\star}-x^{\star}. In the case represented in Fig. 1, where Î¾<0ğœ‰0italic-xi RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0\xi<0 and Î»u<-1subscriptğœ†ğ‘¢1italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1\lambda_{u}<-1, the condition sn+1>xâ‹†subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends_{n+1}>x^{\star} will be satisfied for any Î»s<1subscriptğœ†ğ‘ 1italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1\lambda_{s}<1. This means that for any flip saddle, so long as xâ‹†<sâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star}<s^{\star}, the point xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} will be a fixed point of the controlled dynamics and will be stable so long as -1<ğ’œ<11ğ’œ1ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 RELOP:less-than caligraphic-A RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1-1<{\cal A}<1.

Equations 4 and 5 imply that control can lead to a stable fixed point for any type of fixed point except those for which both Î»usubscriptğœ†ğ‘¢italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{u} and Î»ssubscriptğœ†ğ‘ italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{s} are greater than 1 (so long as -1<ğ’œ<11ğ’œ1ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 RELOP:less-than caligraphic-A RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1-1<{\cal A}<1). Since the required relationship between xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} and sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star} for a stable fixed point of the controlled dynamics depends on the eigenvalues, it is convenient to divide the fixed points into four classes, as given in Table 1

For example, for the non-flip saddle shown in Fig. 2, the natural image of the control line at xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} is above xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star}. Thus, the controlled image will be truncated (vertically) to be identical to xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} and therefore the controller fixed point is also a fixed point of the controlled dynamics. This will be stable for -1<ğ’œ<11ğ’œ1ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 RELOP:less-than caligraphic-A RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1-1<{\cal A}<1, but with a finite basin of attraction.

Beyond the issue of the stability of the fixed point of the controlled dynamics, there is the question of the size of the fixed pointâ€™s basin of attraction. Although the local stability of the fixed point is guaranteed for the cases in Table 1 for -1<ğ’œ<11ğ’œ1ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 RELOP:less-than caligraphic-A RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1-1<{\cal A}<1, the basin of attraction of this fixed point may be small or large depending on ğ’œğ’œcaligraphic-A{\cal A}, ğ’ğ’caligraphic-C{\cal C}, sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star}, Î»usubscriptğœ†ğ‘¢italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{u} and Î»ssubscriptğœ†ğ‘ italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{s}. For the case of Fig. 1, the basin is finite when |Î»s+Î»u-Î»sâ¢Î»u/ğ’œ|>1subscriptğœ†ğ‘ subscriptğœ†ğ‘¢subscriptğœ†ğ‘ subscriptğœ†ğ‘¢ğ’œ1VERTBAR:| italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide caligraphic-A VERTBAR:| RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1|\lambda_{s}+\lambda_{u}-\lambda_{s}\lambda_{u}/{\cal A}|>1. In the case of Fig. 2, and for non-flip repellers generally, any initial condition that is mapped to below the Î»ssubscriptğœ†ğ‘ italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{s} eigenvector will receed away from xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star}. [12]

figure.figcaption: Table 1: Cases which lead to a stable fixed point for the controlled dynamics. In all cases, it is assumed that |ğ’œ|<1ğ’œ1VERTBAR:| caligraphic-A VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1|{\cal A}|<1. (For the cases where Î»s<-1subscriptğœ†ğ‘ 1italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1\lambda_{s}<-1, the subscript sğ‘ italic-ss in Î»ssubscriptğœ†ğ‘ italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{s} is misleading in that the corresponding manifold is unstable. For the spiral, there is no stable manifold.)

div.p: The endpoints of the basin of attraction can be derived analytically[12]. The size of the basin of attraction will often be zero when ğ’œğ’œcaligraphic-A{\cal A} and ğ’ğ’caligraphic-C{\cal C} are chosen to match the stable manifold of the natural system. Therefore, in order to make the basin large, it is advantageous intentionally to misplace the control line and to put xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} in the direction indicated in Table 1. In addition, control may be enhanced by setting ğ’œâ‰ Î»sğ’œsubscriptğœ†ğ‘ caligraphic-A RELOP:not-equals italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal A}\neq\lambda_{s}, for instance ğ’œ=0ğ’œ0caligraphic-A RELOP:equals NUMBER:0{\cal A}=0.

If the relationship between xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} and sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star} is reversed from that given in Table 1, the controlled dynamics will not have a stable fixed points. To some extent, these can also be studied using one-dimensional maps. The flip saddle and double-flip repeller can display stable period-2 orbits and chaos. For the non-flip saddle and single-flip repeller, control is unstable when xâ‹†<sâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star}<s^{\star}.

The fact that control may be successful or even enhanced when ğ’œğ’œcaligraphic-A{\cal A} and ğ’ğ’caligraphic-C{\cal C} are not matched to Î»ssubscriptğœ†ğ‘ italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{s} and sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star} suggests that it may be useful to reverse the experimental procedure often followed in chaos control. Rather than first identifying the parameters of the natural unstable fixed points and then applying the control, one can blindly attempt control and then deduce the natural dynamics from the behavior of the controlled system. This use of PPF control is reminiscent of pioneering studies that used periodic stimulation to demonstrate the complex dynamics of biological preparations[11].
As an example, consider the Henon map:

semantics.annotation: italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.4 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.3 italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: This system has two distinct fixed points. There is a flip-saddle at sâ‹†=0.884superscriptğ‘ â‹†0.884italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.884s^{\star}=0.884 with Î»u=-1.924subscriptğœ†ğ‘¢1.924italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.924\lambda_{u}=-1.924 and Î»s=0.156subscriptğœ†ğ‘ 0.156italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.156\lambda_{s}=0.156 and a non-flip saddle at sâ‹†=-1.584superscriptğ‘ â‹†1.584italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.584s^{\star}=-1.584 with Î»u=3.26subscriptğœ†ğ‘¢3.26italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.26\lambda_{u}=3.26 and Î»s=-0.092subscriptğœ†ğ‘ 0.092italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.092\lambda_{s}=-0.092. In addition, there is an unstable flip-saddle orbit of period 2 following the sequence 1.366â†’-0.666â†’1.366â†’1.3660.666â†’1.366NUMBER:1.366 ARROW:rightarrow ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.666 ARROW:rightarrow NUMBER:1.3661.366\rightarrow-0.666\rightarrow 1.366. There are no real orbits of period 3, but there is an unstable orbit of period 4 following the sequence .893â†’.305â†’1.575â†’-.989â†’.893â†’.893.305â†’1.575â†’.989â†’.893NUMBER:.893 ARROW:rightarrow NUMBER:.305 ARROW:rightarrow NUMBER:1.575 ARROW:rightarrow ADDOP:minus NUMBER:.989 ARROW:rightarrow NUMBER:.893.893\rightarrow.305\rightarrow 1.575\rightarrow-.989\rightarrow.893. These facts can be deduced by algebraic analysis of the equations.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: Bifurcation diagrams for the truncation controlled Henon map. Left: No noise. Right: Dynamical noise added (N(0,0.05)).

div.p: In an experiment using the controlled system, the control parameter xâ‹†=ğ’/(1-ğ’œ)superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğ’1ğ’œitalic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-C MULOP:divide OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus caligraphic-A CLOSE:)x^{\star}={\cal C}/(1-{\cal A}) can be varied. The theory presented above indicates that the controlled system should undergo a bifurcation as xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} passes through sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star}. Figure 3 shows the bifurcation diagram for the controlled Henon system (with ğ’œ=0ğ’œ0caligraphic-A RELOP:equals NUMBER:0{\cal A}=0). For each value of xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star}, the controlled system was iterated from a random initial condition and the values of snsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{n} plotted after allowing a transient to decay[13]. A bifurcation from a stable fixed point to a stable period 2 as xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endx^{\star} passes through the flip-saddle value of sâ‹†=0.884superscriptğ‘ â‹†0.884italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.884s^{\star}=0.884. A different type bifurcation occurs at the non-flip saddle fixed point at sâ‹†=-1.584superscriptğ‘ â‹†1.584italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.584s^{\star}=-1.584. To the left of the bifurcation point, the iterates are diverging to -âˆADDOP:minus ID:infinity-\infty and are not plotted.

Adding gaussian dynamical noise (of standard deviation 0.050.05NUMBER:0.050.05) does not substantially alter the bifurcation diagram, suggesting that examination of the truncation control bifurcation diagram may be a practical way to read off the location of the unstable fixed points in an experimental preparation.

figure.figcaption: Figure 4: Bifurcation diagrams for the truncation controlled Henon map where truncation control is activated only every second (top), third (middle), or fourth (bottom) iteration. Left: No noise. Right: Dynamical noise added (N(0,0.05)). The locations of the true fixed points are marked with vertical lines: F flip-saddle; N non-flip saddle; 2 period-2 orbit; 4 period-4 orbit.

div.p: By activating the truncation control after every second, third or fourth iteration, it is possible to find periodic orbits of period 2, 3, and 4 respectively. The bifurcation diagrams are shown in Fig. 4. The location of the period-2 orbits can be clearly discerned even in the presence of noise. No period-3 orbit is indicated. Noise obscures the location of all but one of the period-4 points.

Unstable periodic orbits can be difficult to find in uncontrolled dynamics because thre is typically little data near such orbits. Application of PPF control, even blindly, can stabilize such orbits and dramatically improve the ability to locate them. This, and the robustness of the control, may prove particularly useful in biological experiments where orbits may drift in time as the properties of the system change. [14]
We would like to acknowledge helpful conversations with Thomas Schreiber and Leon Glass.

li.span: A. Garfinkel, M.L. Spano, W.L. Ditto, J.N. Weiss Science 257:1230-1235 (1992)
S.J. Schiff, K. Jerger, D.H. Duong, T. Chang, M.L. Spano and W.L. Ditto, Nature (London) 370, 614 (1994)
E. Ott, C. Grebogi, and J.A. Yorke Phys. Rev. Lett. 64:1196-1199 (1990)
L. Glass and W. Zeng, Int. J. Bifurcation and Chaos 4:1061 (1994)
D.J. Christini and J.J. Collins, Phys. Rev. Lett. 75:2782-2785 (1995)

A method for identifying unstable fixed points from time series data is described in P. So et al., PRE 55(5):5398-5417 (1997). The relationship between the underlying continuous-time dynamics and the discrete-time map of interspike intervals is discussed in T. Sauer in C.D. Cutler and D.T. Kaplan, eds, Nonlinear Dynamics and Time Series, Fields Inst. Comm. 11 American Mathematical Society, 63-75, (1997) and in M. Ding and W. Yang PRE 55(3):2397-2402 (1997)

This truncation is reminiscent of the mythical Greek inkeeper Procrustes. Travellers too tall for his bed were truncated to fit in a rather gruesome manner. Although PPF originally was intended to stand for â€œProportional Perturbation Feedback,â€ the nonlinear all-or-nothing nature of the perturbation suggests that an alternative expansion is more appropriate: â€œProcrustean Perturbation Feedback.â€

Eq. 3 is simply the linear equation sn+1=aâ¢sn+bâ¢sn-1+csubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1ğ‘italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-a italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-b italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-cs_{n+1}=as_{n}+bs_{n-1}+c with ağ‘italic-aa, bğ‘italic-bb, and cğ‘italic-cc set to give eigenvalues Î»ssubscriptğœ†ğ‘ italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{s} and Î»usubscriptğœ†ğ‘¢italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{u} and fixed point sâ‹†superscriptğ‘ â‹†italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:star POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends^{\star}.

The image of a single point on the control line can be found graphically using the cobweb method. From the point, trace horizontally to the line of identity, then vertically to the image of the control line. If following the natural dynamics, trace to the natural image. If following the controlled dynamics, trace toward the natural image but stop at the control line if that is below the natural image.
M.R. Guevara, L. Glass, A. Shrier, Science 214:1350-53 (1981)
Details will be provided in a subsequent communication.

No attempt was made to wait until the system state naturally approached a putative fixed point. The truncation control was active at all time. The decay of the transient typically took only a few iterations.
An example of such drifts and their influence on control is found in K. Hall et al. (ibid) and D.J. Gauthier and J.E.S. Socolar, Phys. Rev. Let., Vol. 79, p. 4938 (1997).
